description: From Middle English kilne, from Old English cylene or cyline (“large oven”), from Latin culīna (“kitchen, kitchen stove”).
The pronunciation with /n/ is probably a spelling pronunciation, but may have been supported by dialects where /ln/ was not simplified to /l/.

entries.meaning: An oven or furnace or a heated chamber, for the purpose of hardening, burning, calcining or drying anything; for example, firing ceramics, curing or preserving tobacco, or drying grain.

verbs.description: kiln (third-person singular simple present kilns, present participle kilning, simple past and past participle kilned)

entries.meaning: To bake in a kiln; to fire.
examples: When making pottery we need to allow the bisque to dry before we kiln it.
